main event: Multiple radar sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) were reported near Keflavik, Iceland, on 25th February and 13th March 1952. The objects exhibited unusual behavior and high speeds, and poor weather conditions hindered visual confirmation.
interesting points: The radar targets were observed during Ground Control Approach (GCA) runs with a local C-47 aircraft.

The objects' speed was reported to be much faster than known aircraft, such as the F-86, and their altitude was estimated to be above 50,000 feet, indicating capabilities beyond conventional aircraft of the time.
The radarscope targets, known as 'ghosts or angels,' displayed consistent speed and track, often appearing and disappearing, posing challenges in identification.
Efforts to intercept or visually confirm the targets were impeded by poor weather conditions, contributing to the overall mystery of the sightings.
The objects were tracked for approximately 10 minutes during the observation period, raising questions about the nature and origin of the unidentified targets.
sighted object: unidentified flying objects (UFOs) exhibiting high speeds and unconventional behavior
witnesses: USAF personnel and GCA crew chief
